ğ“ƒ¹ ğ“ˆ– ğ“ƒ€ ğ“ƒ¢ â€¢Cuon alpinus "white dog" <> ğ“ƒ¹ ğ“ˆ– cunÄ«culus ÎºÏŒÎ½Î¹ÎºÎ»Î¿Ï‚ kÃ³niklos â€kleiner Kuonâ€œ çŠ¬

ğ’Œ¨ğ’† ğ’‰Œ hal-ki-ni á¸ªUL.ÎºÏon çŠ¬ quÇn chien canis @ Elamite â‡” karne ğ“ƒ¹  

[[ğ“ƒ©]] Dagan ğ’€­ğ’…   ğ’€­ğ’•[[ğ’ƒ¶]]  originally a weather-god  

First animal to be domesticated by man.  

An extinct Late Pleistocene wolf which may have been the ancestor of the dog split from other wolf lineages between 20,000 and 40,000 years ago. Domestication must have occured later. The Bonn-Oberkassel dog buried beside humans 14,200 years ago is the first undisputed dog. The dog was domesticated in Eurasia, either Central Asia, East Asia or Western Europe.  

[[ANE]] Ancient North Eurasian  

"It has been suggested that their mythology may have included a narrative, found in both Indo-European and Native American fables, in which a dog guards the path to the afterlife." [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_North_Eurasian)  

Domestication of the dog in Siberia?

Doctors  
-------  
Two Eurasian (+American) mysts:  
1.) Keeper of Hell  
2.) Doctors â‡” Dog[[Tier]]  

Nintinuga was the Babylonian goddess of medicine and wife of the god Ninurta ğ’€­ğ’Š©[[ğ’Œ†]] [[ğ’…]]. The goddess is identifying with the Acad goddess Bau (ğ’€­ğ’€ğ’Œ‘ Dbau) or Baba and accompanied or represented by dogs â‡” Humbaba?  
Gula after the First Babylonian Dynasty.  

The most prominent cult centre of ğ’€­ğ’Š©ğ’Œ†ğ’‹¼ğ’€€ğ’Šğ’€ Gula/Ninkarrak/Ninisinna was Isin ğ’‰Œğ’‹›ğ’…”ğ’† ,  
where her temple as named ğ’‚ğ’Œ‘ğ’‚ ğ’Š Ã©-u-gi7-ra "Dog Temple"
